body: @nathanielmanistaatgoogle

Thank you for the report! Marking this a duplicate of [issue 5913](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/5913).

We're working on some pretty dramatic improvements to gRPC Python that should land in the next few weeks.
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle thanks for your response, but i saw the mentioned issue only indicates the memory leak on server side. Are you sure the memory leak on client side is also working?
For anyone else stumbling across this: the defect identified here was fixed in [pull request 6711](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/6711).
great done

Hi, @nathanielmanistaatgoogle ,

I use grpcio(0.15.0). and I found the memory of python client will still grow and grow.

 [The demo](https://github.com/zj8487/helloworld) show how i use grpc.

@zj8487: your demo at [this point](https://github.com/zj8487/helloworld/tree/7e6a1c595f96373ecb35790016a1f7211a2e4d6e) seems pretty complicated - are you able to strip any of it away and still maintain demonstration of unbounded memory growth? Also are you able to do any Python-level analysis of what is residing in the memory that is being leaked? What kinds of Python objects, if it is Python objects that are being leaked?

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle 
Thanks your response, I will strip the demo and do some Python-level analysis and the post it here this weekend

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle   [The demo](https://github.com/zj8487/helloworld) is updated.

**The output indicates the memory of client is growing slowly.**

The memory of the process of the **begin time** is shown as follow:
![1_meitu_1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5138447/16545658/b5236530-4163-11e6-89bb-d0d6a6a88d36.jpg)

The memory of the process of the **end time** is shown as follow:
![2_meitu_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5138447/16545299/56a99ef2-4159-11e6-87a1-f9bd2439447d.jpg)

**But the python objects of the process show there is no python object leak**

The python objects of the process at the **begin time** as follow:

```
_The gc infomation when request count is 170000_
gc: collecting generation 0...
gc: objects in each generation: 13725 72 23009
gc: done, 0.0021s elapsed.
gc: collecting generation 0...
gc: objects in each generation: 4296 10322 23009
gc: done, 0.0008s elapsed.
gc: collecting generation 0...
gc: objects in each generation: 839 14600 23009
gc: done, 0.0002s elapsed.
```

The python objects of the process at the **end time** as follow:

```
_The gc infomation when request count is 21610000_
gc: collecting generation 0...
gc: objects in each generation: 4023 0 23009
gc: done, 0.0030s elapsed.
gc: collecting generation 0...
gc: objects in each generation: 4414 0 23009
gc: done, 0.0020s elapsed.
gc: collecting generation 0...
gc: objects in each generation: 4239 0 23009
gc: done, 0.0011s elapsed.
gc: collecting generation 0...
```

@zj8487: thank you for your investigation. What version of Python are you using?

In your code I notice that you're using [`stub.SayHello.future(<arguments>)`](https://github.com/zj8487/helloworld/blob/5d872ba47f57a337381d0a5ee076d1e68412e86f/greeter_client.py#L71) to make asynchronous requests - is this necessary for demonstrating the memory leak or can it be changed? If you change that line to `ignored_response = stub.SayHello(<arguments>)`, does the memory leak continue to manifest?

Also I notice that [your callback](https://github.com/zj8487/helloworld/blob/5d872ba47f57a337381d0a5ee076d1e68412e86f/greeter_client.py#L52) doesn't seem to print anything, but it does call a few methods on the `Future` object passed to it (`code`, `exception`, and `result`). Are these calls part of demonstrating the memory leak? What happens if you change the body of your callback to just `pass`?

Have you tried reproducing the leak using the (new) [GA API](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/release-0_15/src/python/grpcio/grpc/__init__.py)? You may have to rerun the code generator to produce a helloworld_pb2.py that includes the non-`beta` classes and functions.

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle :Thank you for your response.

**What version of Python are you using?**

```
python2.7.x
```

**Dose synchronous requests leak?**

```
I tried the synchronous requests yesterday, and i did not notice the memory grow.
```

*_Why did not print something in the callback? *_

```
just not want some useless output
```

**Have you tried reproducing the leak using the (new) GA API?**

```
Not yet, i will try it today.
```

**What happens if you change the body of your callback to just pass?**

```
I test it for few minutes and notice that the memory grow as well, and it seems to grow more quickly
```

[This pull request](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/7177) shows how to generate a new helloworld_pb2.py. Make sure you have the latest [grpcio](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/grpcio) and [grpcio-tools](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/grpcio-tools) installed in your Python environment.

I update **the client to use the GA API** and notice two things:
1.  The memory of client is still growing.
2. If the server raise error, the memory of client grows more quickly

```
class Greeter(helloworld_pb2.BetaGreeterServicer):

    def SayHello(self, request, context):
        raise NameError("test err1111111111111111")
```
[I'm not yet seeing your latest code](https://github.com/zj8487/helloworld/blob/master/greeter_client.py)?

updated
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle

Let's keep working toward the smallest possible code that demonstrates the defect. If the defect still manifests when the body of your callback is reduced to just `pass`, go ahead and reduce the body of your callback to just `pass`. If you eliminate adding the callback to the future, does the leak still take place? Timeouts are not required in the GA API - if you eliminate passing a timeout, does the leak still take place?

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle

timeout is eliminated for all the following test

case 1: `The body of callback is reduced to just pass`
**the memory is growing**

```
def grpc_done_cb(future_response):
    pass


def run():
    channel = insecure_channel('localhost:50051')
    stub = helloworld_pb2.GreeterStub(channel)
    counter = 1
    while True:
        response = stub.SayHello.future(helloworld_pb2.HelloRequest(name='you'))
        response.add_done_callback(grpc_done_cb)
        time.sleep(0.0004)
        counter += 1
        if counter % 10000 == 0:
            print("============================================================Print the request count:", counter)
```

case 2: `Eliminate adding the callback to the future`
**the memory is not growing**

```
def run():
    channel = insecure_channel('localhost:50051')
    stub = helloworld_pb2.GreeterStub(channel)
    counter = 1
    while True:
        response = stub.SayHello.future(helloworld_pb2.HelloRequest(name='you'))
        time.sleep(0.0004)
        counter += 1
        if counter % 10000 == 0:
            print("============================================================Print the request count:", counter)

```
What's the rate of memory leak in bytes/second? Does the code you just posted demonstrate the fastest leak?
What's with the `sleep` in your code? Is that critical to demonstrating the leak?
it is just want to control the speed of request.
Can you increase the rate of leak by lowering the sleep time?

Now i am testing the case `The server's method return normally based on the body of callback is reduced to just pass`

I will test it several hours later for a short sleep time
If you change `'you'` to `'you'*100000`, does the rate of leak increase?

Case: Testing the case The server's method return normally based on the body of callback is reduced to just pass and change 'you' to 'you'*100000, does the rate of leak increase?

it grow quickly and quickly, one words: very quickly

another issue:`Ctrl + C` can not make the client to exit

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "greeter_client.py", line 70, in <module>
    run()
  File "greeter_client.py", line 61, in run
    response = stub.SayHello.future(helloworld_pb2.HelloRequest(name='you'))
  File "/home/xxxx/.virtualenvs/xxxx/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 477, in future
    request, timeout, metadata)
  File "/home/xxx/.virtualenvs/xxxx/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 440, in _prepare
    state = _RPCState(_UNARY_UNARY_INITIAL_DUE, None, None, None, None)
  File "/home/xxxx/.virtualenvs/xxxx/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 109, in __init__
    self.due = set(due)
KeyboardInterrupt
^C^CE0704 17:57:48.988460597   29195 chttp2_transport.c:1810]    close_transport: {"created":"@1467626268.959884871","description":"Failed parsing HTTP/2","file":"src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/transport/chttp2_transport.c","file_line":1726,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1467626268.959881826","description":"EOF","file":"src/core/lib/iomgr/tcp_posix.c","file_line":233}]}
^C^C^C

```

I'm able to reproduce the leak with no `sleep` at all, so no need to experiment with varying values for the sleep.

I've just noticed that the server's memory is also growing, though not as rapidly as the client's.

If you're able to work from source [the `Ctrl-C` issue is fixed there](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3820).

I can't do this at the moment (and may not try it tomorrow - kinda sick), but: it might be worth inspecting the `gc` module to see which Python/Cython types are leaking and who owns the leaked instances (reference cycle vs. dangling root, if it's the Cython `Buffer` type then who's holding on, etc.).
